metadata.title: Load Test Post-Mortem: Checkout Flow Capacity Validation (LT-2025-Q3-CHECKOUT)
metadata.author: Kai Johannsen (QA Performance Engineering)

actions: Kai ran 48-hour sustained load test simulating Black Friday traffic levels on checkout flow
Peak simulated load: 12,000 concurrent users, 2,800 orders/minute through checkout-service
checkout-service p99 latency reached 890ms at peak (SLA target: <1000ms) — PASS
payment-gateway sustained 3,100 TPS with 99.97% success rate — 0.03% failures were gateway timeouts to payment processor sandbox
inventory-lock-service hit connection pool exhaustion at 2,400 concurrent locks — pool max was 2,000; auto-scaled to 3 replicas which resolved it
cart-service showed memory leak under sustained load — RSS grew from 512MB to 1.8GB over 36 hours before GC reclaimed; filed bug VC-QA-2891
Overall: checkout flow meets Black Friday capacity targets with minor inventory-lock scaling concern and cart-service memory issue
quotes: Test Summary: 48-hour sustained load. Peak: 12,000 concurrent users. Total orders processed: 3,847,291. Success rate: 99.94%. Mean latency: 342ms. p95: 612ms. p99: 890ms. Max: 2,104ms.

inventory-lock-service: Connection pool exhausted at T+6h14m. Pool config: max_connections=2000, wait_timeout=5s. HPA scaled from 2 to 3 replicas at T+6h16m. Pool pressure resolved by T+6h19m. Recommend: increase base pool to 2500 or set HPA threshold lower.

cart-service: RSS memory growth observed. T+0h: 512MB. T+12h: 980MB. T+24h: 1.4GB. T+36h: 1.8GB. GC triggered at 1.8GB, dropped to 620MB. Suspect: session object cache not evicting expired entries. Bug filed: VC-QA-2891.
details: Locust script: scenarios/checkout_flow_bf2025.py — simulates browse, add-to-cart, apply-coupon, checkout, payment
Database load during peak: orders-db-primary IOPS 14,200 (capacity 20,000), replication lag 0.3s
Redis cache hit rate for product prices: 97.2% during test (normal: 98.1%)
No data loss observed — reconciliation of order count in Locust vs orders-db matched within 0.01%
Test used sandboxed payment processor (Stripe test mode) — no real transactions
Staging cluster node sizes: 8x m5.2xlarge (8 vCPU, 32GB RAM), matching production node spec
Network: inter-service latency in staging-perf averages 0.4ms (production averages 0.3ms)

metadata.title: GDPR Data Processing Impact Assessment — Recommendation Engine Personalization Feature
metadata.author: Elena Marchetti (Data Protection Officer)
metadata.feature: Enhanced product recommendations based on browsing history

entities: Vantage Commerce EU customer base (estimated 2.1M users)
actions: Elena Marchetti initiated DPIA for new personalization feature that extends recommendation engine to use 90-day browsing history
Current state: recommendations use only purchase history and explicit preferences (GDPR lawful basis: contract performance)
Proposed state: add browsing history as additional signal — requires legitimate interest assessment or consent
Data mapping completed: browsing-history-collector sends anonymized page-view events to recommendation engine — no direct identifiers in event payload, linked via pseudonymized user token
Retention assessment: browsing history proposed at 90 days with automated deletion — Elena requested reduction to 60 days
Legal department reviewing whether legitimate interest applies or explicit consent is required for EU users
Elena confirmed that browsing data does not leave EU-WEST-1 region — no cross-border transfer concern
quotes: DPIA Summary: Feature 'Enhanced Personalization v2'. Data subjects: ~2.1M EU users. Data elements: page URLs (product pages only), timestamp, session duration, pseudonymized user token. No direct identifiers. Retention: 90 days proposed, 60 days recommended.

Lawful Basis Assessment: Contract performance (Art. 6(1)(b)) covers purchase-based recommendations. Browsing-based recommendations likely require legitimate interest (Art. 6(1)(f)) with balancing test, or consent (Art. 6(1)(a)). Legal review in progress.

Technical Safeguards: Pseudonymization via SHA-256 hash of user_id + daily salt. No raw user_id in browsing-history-collector datastore. Re-identification requires access to user-profile-service mapping table (access restricted to 3 engineers).
details: DPIA reference: DPIA-2025-017
Expected completion: 2025-10-20
Feature launch blocked pending DPIA approval
Previous DPIA (DPIA-2025-012, email marketing) completed in 14 days — same DPO
Browsing-history-collector processes approximately 4.2M events/day for EU users
Data subject access request (DSAR) process tested: browsing data exportable in <24 hours
EU supervisory authority (Irish DPC) notified of DPIA initiation per company policy
